page.title: 04SILVERWOOD COLLIERY
page.content: {Silverwood Colliery}has{two shafts}to go underground. These two shafts were dug in{1900}and the{first coal}to come out of the pit was in{1905.}There have been two{Royal Visits}to Silverwood. The first one was in{1912}when{King {George V}visited it and the second was in{1975}when{Queen Elizabeth II, } our present Queen went there. The {largest area}of coal was the{Barnsley seam, which gave coal for over{fifty {years.}They now work at the{Swallow {Wood}seam, which is two metres deep. Each week it produces{seven thousand tons. There are more than{thirty {million tons left}to keep them going. The coal from Silverwood goes to various places. Three quarters of it goes to{British Steel}and the remainder goes to power stations and houses and homes to provide heating and hot water.
